articles.headline: A Software Maker Goes Up Against Microsoft
articles.snippet: VMware is the early leader in a fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, putting it on a collision course with Microsoft.
articles.abstract: VMware is the early leader in a fast-growing market for virtual-machine software, putting it on a collision course with Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: VMware, a young Silicon Valley company, is the early leader in a fast-growing market for what is called virtual-machine software. And that puts it on a collision course with Microsoft, the industry’s Goliath.

articles.headline: U.S. Seizes Son of a Top Shiite, Stirring Uproar
articles.snippet: The detention of Abdul Aziz al-Hakim's eldest son agitated one of Iraq’s most formidable political movements.
articles.abstract: The detention of Abdul Aziz al-Hakim's eldest son agitated one of Iraq’s most formidable political movements.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 23 — American troops seized and then released the eldest son of Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, perhaps the most powerful Shiite political leader in Iraq, after he crossed the border from Iran into Iraq on Friday morning.

articles.headline: Canadian Court Limits Detention in Terror Cases
articles.snippet: The decision reflected striking differences from the current legal climate in the United States.
articles.abstract: The decision reflected striking differences from the current legal climate in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Feb. 23  Canada’s highest court on Friday unanimously struck down a law that allows the Canadian government to detain foreign-born terrorism suspects indefinitely using secret evidence and without charges while their deportations are being reviewed.

articles.headline: A Contract Is a Contract, Right?
articles.snippet: So what would you do if you ran State Farm’s Mississippi operation?
articles.abstract: So what would you do if you ran State Farm’s Mississippi operation?
articles.lead_paragraph: So what would you do if you ran State Farm’s Mississippi operation?

articles.headline: Record Fine Expected for Univision
articles.snippet: The $24 million fine is a tough rebuke to Univision for passing off Latino soap operas as children’s programming.
articles.abstract: The $24 million fine is a tough rebuke to Univision for passing off Latino soap operas as children’s programming.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 — When Univision began broadcasting a show three years ago about the misadventures of 11-year-old identical twin girls who swapped identities after discovering they had been separated at birth, it characterized the episodes as educational programming for children.

articles.headline: Family Hands Off Its Business, and Its Philosophy
articles.snippet: The wrenching job of handing over a family business to outsiders can be as quirky as the founding family.
articles.abstract: The wrenching job of handing over a family business to outsiders can be as quirky as the founding family.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLAND, Mich. — Right up there with putting an aging parent in a nursing home stands the wrenching job of handing over a family business to be run by outsiders.

articles.headline: When Disillusion Sets In
articles.snippet: The death of a Quiznos franchise owner illustrates a growing sense of desperation and frustration toward the corporation.
articles.abstract: The death of a Quiznos franchise owner illustrates a growing sense of desperation and frustration toward the corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 27, Bhupinder Baber walked into a Quiznos restaurant on the outskirts of Los Angeles. He spoke briefly with the manager before stepping into the restroom and shooting himself three times in the chest.

articles.headline: New Airport X-Rays Scan Bodies, Not Just Bags
articles.snippet: The device peeks underneath passengers’ clothing to search for guns, bombs or liquid explosives.
articles.abstract: The device peeks underneath passengers’ clothing to search for guns, bombs or liquid explosives.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX, Feb. 23 — X-ray vision has come to the airport checkpoint here, courtesy of federal aviation security officials who have installed a new device that peeks underneath passengers’ clothing to search for guns, bombs or liquid explosives.
articles.byline: By Paul Giblin and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: At $45 Billion, New Contender for Top Buyout
articles.snippet: A group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group is near a deal to acquire the TXU Corporation.
articles.abstract: A group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group is near a deal to acquire the TXU Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest leveraged buyout ever is about to be surpassed. Again.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Think Your Social Security Number Is Secure? Think Again
articles.snippet: Now there are tools available online to safeguard against the theft of Social Security numbers.
articles.abstract: Now there are tools available online to safeguard against the theft of Social Security numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It should come as little surprise that Social Security numbers are posted on the Internet. But, says Betty Ostergren, a former insurance claims supervisor in suburban Richmond, Va., who has spent years trolling for them, “people are always astounded” to learn that theirs is one of them.

articles.headline: In Big Buyout, Utility to Limit New Coal Plants
articles.snippet: The TXU Corporation, the bane of environmental groups, will commit to a broad menu of environmental measures.
articles.abstract: The TXU Corporation, the bane of environmental groups, will commit to a broad menu of environmental measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under a proposed $45 billion buyout by a team of private equity firms, the TXU Corporation, a Texas utility that has long been the bane of environmental groups, will abandon plans to build 8 of 11 coal plants and commit to a broad menu of environmental measures, according to people involved in the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Felicity Barringer and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Christian Right Labors to Find ’08 Candidate
articles.snippet: A pivotal group of Christian conservatives is dissatisfied with the Republican presidential field and uncertain where to turn.
articles.abstract: A pivotal group of Christian conservatives is dissatisfied with the Republican presidential field and uncertain where to turn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 — A group of influential Christian conservatives and their allies emerged from a private meeting at a Florida resort this month dissatisfied with the Republican presidential field and uncertain where to turn.

articles.headline: Of Tax Cuts and Those $10 Million Bat Mitzvahs
articles.snippet: We’re in a war that the government cannot afford to pay, but the society at home is routinely having million-dollar bar mitzvahs?
articles.abstract: We’re in a war that the government cannot afford to pay, but the society at home is routinely having million-dollar bar mitzvahs?
articles.lead_paragraph: TWENTY-FOUR hours in the life of my rapidly aging brain:

articles.headline: Iraq Rebel Cleric Reins In Militia; Motives at Issue
articles.snippet: Moktada al-Sadr seems to be cooperating with the latest effort to pacify Baghdad, but why he is doing so remains unclear.
articles.abstract: Moktada al-Sadr seems to be cooperating with the latest effort to pacify Baghdad, but why he is doing so remains unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 24 — Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric and founder of the Mahdi Army militia, discovered recently that two of his commanders had created DVDs of their men killing Sunnis in Baghdad. Documents suggested that they had received money from Iran.

articles.headline: This Time, No Roadside Assistance
articles.snippet: Back then, it was Lee Iacocca and the federal government bailing out Chrysler. Today the German owners must figure out how to fix the company.
articles.abstract: Back then, it was Lee Iacocca and the federal government bailing out Chrysler. Today the German owners must figure out how to fix the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich.

articles.headline: Rivals on Legal Tightrope Seek to Expand Freedoms in China
articles.snippet: Two advocates of the rule of law differ on whether to work within the system or to seek an end to Communist rule.
articles.abstract: Two advocates of the rule of law differ on whether to work within the system or to seek an end to Communist rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Li Jinsong and Li Jianqiang are Chinese trial lawyers who take on difficult political cases, tangle with the police and seek solace in the same religion, Christianity.

articles.headline: Some Respect, Please, for the Afternoon Nap
articles.snippet: More studies show that short periods of sleep during the day increase productivity and creativity while reducing stress.
articles.abstract: More studies show that short periods of sleep during the day increase productivity and creativity while reducing stress.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINDERGARTNERS fight against naptime because they want to be just like the grown-ups. But those grown-ups would give anything for a chance to close their eyes during the endless time between lunch and dinner.

articles.headline: Young Lawyers Sue, and Little Changes
articles.snippet: Young lawyers who sued BAR/BRI contending that it operated an illegal monopoly complain that a proposed settlement lets the company off the hook too lightly.
articles.abstract: Young lawyers who sued BAR/BRI contending that it operated an illegal monopoly complain that a proposed settlement lets the company off the hook too lightly.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMPETITORS say that a leading company ripped down their posters and used deceptive marketing tactics; former customers say that the same company paid business rivals to close their doors. And one competitor says he fears that he was the victim of outright theft.

articles.headline: Nation of Islam at a Crossroad as Leader Exits
articles.snippet: Questions loom about the future of the Nation of Islam after Louis Farrakhan.
articles.abstract: Questions loom about the future of the Nation of Islam after Louis Farrakhan.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Feb. 25 — Louis Farrakhan, the departing leader of the Nation of Islam, gave what was billed as his last major public address here on Sunday, with his extended illness throwing into sharp focus the question of whether the group will shift toward more mainstream Islamic teachings to survive once it loses its central charismatic figure.

articles.headline: Bush to Warn Pakistan to Act on Terror
articles.snippet: President Bush will send a tough message to President Pervez Musharraf that U.S. aid could be cut unless he becomes more aggressive in hunting Al Qaeda leaders.
articles.abstract: President Bush will send a tough message to President Pervez Musharraf that U.S. aid could be cut unless he becomes more aggressive in hunting Al Qaeda leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 — President Bush has decided to send an unusually tough message to one of his most important allies, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, warning him that the newly Democratic Congress could cut aid to his country unless his forces become far more aggressive in hunting down operatives with Al Qaeda, senior administration officials say.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Citigroup Finds Taker for Hard Job
articles.snippet: Gary L. Crittenden, an American Express executive, has been named Citigroup’s chief financial officer, a post that puts him on a path to succeed Charles O. Prince III.
articles.abstract: Gary L. Crittenden, an American Express executive, has been named Citigroup’s chief financial officer, a post that puts him on a path to succeed Charles O. Prince III.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about a tough job description: Help wanted. Chief financial officer for one of the world's largest banks. Must be able to reverse a course of underperformance for which the company's chief executive has taken the blame.

articles.headline: As Candidate, Obama Carves Antiwar Stance
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama is running for president as one of the few candidates who opposed the Iraq war from the beginning.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama is running for president as one of the few candidates who opposed the Iraq war from the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 — Senator Barack Obama is running for president as one of the few candidates who opposed the Iraq war from the beginning, a simple position unburdened by expressions of regret or decisions over whether to apologize for initially supporting the invasion.

articles.headline: An Ad Upstart Challenges Google
articles.snippet: Yahoo and Google are facing a challenge from a tiny adversary named Quigo Technologies over contextual text ads online.
articles.abstract: Yahoo and Google are facing a challenge from a tiny adversary named Quigo Technologies over contextual text ads online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google and Yahoo have been fighting it out over which company will dominate the online advertising business, with Google maintaining the upper hand so far.

articles.headline: Seeking Skills, Indians Find Career Path to Sky
articles.snippet: Young Indians are pursuing careers unavailable to their parents, and new private airlines provide opportunities.
articles.abstract: Young Indians are pursuing careers unavailable to their parents, and new private airlines provide opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Feb. 24 — This is a story that Abhinanda Shukla, 25, is fond of telling at job interviews, so perfectly honed that it has the ring of an overdrawn fairy tale.

articles.headline: Someone Give Geffen a Day Job
articles.snippet: There is a danger that if the coming election becomes David Geffen’s full-time hobby, his precision ruthlessness will distort the public process.
articles.abstract: There is a danger that if the coming election becomes David Geffen’s full-time hobby, his precision ruthlessness will distort the public process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: New Hot Properties: YouTube Celebrities
articles.snippet: The most popular YouTubers are being wooed by other video Web sites with promises of exposure and money.
articles.abstract: The most popular YouTubers are being wooed by other video Web sites with promises of exposure and money.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one would mistake the Ask a Jew guy for Lonelygirl15, but these days YouTube contributor Shmuel Tennenhaus is feeling like a hot commodity.

articles.headline: For TXU, One of the Street’s Fabled Barbarians Is Back in the Hunt
articles.snippet: Henry R. Kravis, whose role in the RJR Nabisco buyout was the inspiration for “Barbarians at the Gate,” is at it again, with a proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU.
articles.abstract: Henry R. Kravis, whose role in the RJR Nabisco buyout was the inspiration for “Barbarians at the Gate,” is at it again, with a proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has been there, done that, and now, close to 20 years after clinching the grandest buyout deal ever, Henry R. Kravis seems to be doing it again.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Raid in Iraq Supports Claim on Iran
articles.snippet: A raid on a Shiite weapons cache is cited as evidence of Iranian involvement, but critics contend the case remains circumstantial.
articles.abstract: A raid on a Shiite weapons cache is cited as evidence of Iranian involvement, but critics contend the case remains circumstantial.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 25 — A raid on a Shiite weapons cache in the southern city of Hilla one week ago is providing what American officials call the best evidence yet that the deadliest roadside bombs in Iraq are manufactured in Iran, but critics contend that the forensic case remains circumstantial and inferential.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Richard A. Oppel Jr
